title: 105_hr2442
content: The text chunk is too short to provide a meaningful summary. The "Fairness for Immigrants Facing Persecution in Their Native Country Act of 1997" amends section 240A of the Immigration and Nationality Act, specifying changes related to deportation and adjustment of status. The amendments apply to removal cases initiated on or after April 1, 1997. Section 309(c) of the Illegal Immigration Reform and Immigrant Responsibility Act of 1996 is amended by removing paragraph (7). Additionally, Section 240A of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include changes in subsections (b) and (d). The Attorney General may cancel removal and adjust the status of certain aliens who demonstrate they have not been convicted of an aggravated felony, including Haitians who applied for asylum before October 15. The Attorney General may cancel removal and adjust the status of certain aliens who have not been convicted of an aggravated felony. This includes Haitians who applied for asylum before October 15, 1994, and were not granted, denied, or referred by the Immigration and Naturalization Service as of April 1, 1997. Additionally, those who were paroled into the United States before October 15, 1994, and were not apprehended after December 19, 1990, at the time of entry, may also file for asylum. Salvadoran and Guatemalan nationals who entered the US before specific dates and met certain criteria are eligible for benefits or Temporary Protected Status. Salvadoran and Guatemalan nationals eligible for benefits under the ABC settlement agreement must have registered by December 31, 1991. Spouses or unmarried children of eligible aliens who entered the US before specific dates are also included. The text chunk discusses eligibility criteria for certain nationals from Nicaragua, Guatemala, and El Salvador to apply for asylum before specific dates. The text chunk outlines the eligibility requirements for an alien to apply for asylum in the United States, including being physically present for at least seven years, proving good moral character, and demonstrating extreme hardship if removed. The alien must demonstrate extreme hardship to themselves or their family who are US citizens or lawful permanent residents, or have been physically present in the US for at least 10 years after committing an act that makes them removable. The alien must prove good moral character and show exceptional hardship to US citizen or lawful permanent resident family members to avoid deportation. The amendments in this section exempt certain aliens from continuous physical presence requirements and are retroactively effective. Aliens eligible for suspension of deportation or cancellation of removal due to these changes have no other limitations. Aliens eligible for suspension of deportation or cancellation of removal, as per section 2, may file one motion to reopen within a designated time period, exempt from other limitations. The period starts within 120 days of enactment and lasts for 180 days.
